castItem.roleDesc: a young Carthaginian, living at Calydon.

body.stage: Scene--Calydon, a city of tolia. Before the houses of AGORASTOCLES and LYOUS, and the Temple of Venus.

div2.head: THE SUBJECT
div2.p: THERE were two cousins, citizens of Carthage; the daughters of one of them named Hanno, were stolen in their childhood, and being carried off to Calydon, were there purchased by Lycus, a Procurer. In the same place there is living Agorastocles, the son of the cousin of Hanno, who, having been stolen in his infancy, was sold to a wealthy old man, and finally adopted by him. Here, without knowing their relationship, Agorastocles falls in love with Adelphasium, the elder of the sisters, while Anthemonides, a military officer, entertains a passion for Anterastylis, the younger sister. The Procurer being at enmity with Agorastocles, the latter, with the assistance of his servant Milphio, devises a plan for outwitting him. Collybiscus, the bailiff of Agorastocles, is dressed up as a foreigner, and, a sum of money being given him for the purpose, pretends to take up his abode in the house of Lycus. On this being effected, by previous arrangement Agorastocles comes with witnesses, and accuses the Procurer of harbouring his slave, and encouraging him to rob his master. At this conjuncture, Hanno arrives at Calydon in search of his daughters. He discovers them, and finds that Agorastocles is the son of his deceased cousin. The play ends with the removal of the damsels from the house of Lycus, who is brought to task for his iniquities; and Adelphasium is promised by her father in marriage to Agorastocles.

note.#text: [Supposed to have been written by Priscian the Grammarian.]

p.#text: A BOY (), seven years old, is stolen at Carthage. An old man, a hater () of women, adopts him when bought, and () makes him his heir. His two kinswomen and their nurse () are  carried off. Lycus buys them and torments ()  in love. But he palms off his bailiff with some gold upon the Procurer (),  so convicts him of theft. Hanno, the Carthaginian, comes (), discovers him  the son of his cousin, and recognizes his own () daughters whom he had lost.

note.#text: Title :  Cicero uses the word "Pnulus," as signifying merely "a Carthaginian." It is difficult to say whether the Play is so styled in reference to Hanno, merely as a citizen of Carthage, or whether the word refers to the young man Agorastocles, in the sense of the "young Carthaginian." From an expression used in the Fifth Act, "a man's great toe," it would appear that Hanno was represented on the stage as a person of diminutive stature; in consequence of which, it has been suggested that the meaning is "the little Carthaginian." Lipsius thinks that this Prologue was not written by Plautus, and indeed some scholars suspect the whole Play to be spurious.

:  Aristarchus was a Tragic Poet, the contemporary of Euripides, and flourished about 250 years before the time of Plautus. His Tragedy of Achilles no longer exists. We are informed by Festus that it was translated into Latin by the Poet Eunius.
:  "Bonum factum est." Literally, "it is a good deed." This was a stated form, placed at the commencement of Roman edicts and proclamations, as ensuring a good omen.

:  "Scortum exoletum." As the word "scortum" may apply to either sex, it is not improbable that this is intended as a notice to the old and battered debauchees, that they are not to take the liberty of occupying the front of the stage, as perhaps, in their effrontery, they had lately been in the habit of doing.
:  These "virg" were used by the lictors for the purposes of punishment, and if stiff and hard, would be likely to make a noise when struck against any object.
:  "Designator." It was the duty of this officer to point out to persons their seats.
:  It has been previously remarked that only standing room was provided in the theatres for the slaves.

:  "s pro capite." The meaning of this term, as here used, is not exactly known. Some think that it means, that if the slaves want seats, let them pay down money for their freedom, on which they will be entitled to them. It is not improbable that the phase means, "let them pay money for their seats;" and Muretus supposes that the right of letting out certain seats was reserved by the actors as their own perquisite.
:  This is not the only place where Plautus refers to the love which the Roman nurses had for the bottle.
:  "Scriblit." These were a kind of tarts or cakes which had letters stamped upon them, and were probably so called from , "to write."
:  "Carchedonius," the old Roman name for "Carthaginian," from  the Greek for "Carthage."

:  "Patruus pultiphagonides." The Roman "puls," or "pottage," was composed of meat, water, honey, cheese, and eggs. There was a particular sort of "puls," called "puls Punica," or "Punic pottage." As this Play was written at the period of the second Carthaginian war, Plautus would not object to hold their enemies up to contempt as mere "porridge-eaters."

:  "Fratres fratrueles." "Sons of brothers." This clears up all the confusion that otherwise seems to exist in the Play, by reason of Agorastocles continually calling Hanno his "patruus," which Warner (to avoid confusion, as he says) translates "uncle." It is pretty clear that "patruus" was a term extending not only to uncles, but to other collateral relatives of the father; not only father's brothers, but father's cousins.
:  "Pollinctor." This was properly the servant of the "libitinarius," or "undertaker." See the Asinaria, l. 916, and the Note.

:  "Sine viatico." Literally, "without provisions for the journey." This, probably, simply means that he died suddenly and unexpectedly. Some think that it refers to the ceremony of placing a piece of money in the mouths of the dead, for payment to Charon, on ferrying them over the Styx. If so, the allusion here appears to be very purposeless.
: --. These two lines also occur almost verbatim in the Menchmi, l. 54-5.

:  "Magalia," or "magara," was a name given to the huts or cottages peculiar to the neighbourhood of Carthage. The word, probably, here means a suburb of that city, which received its name from these huts, and was used by the inhabitants as a public walk.
:  This was a town of Acarnania, in Greece.
:  From the Greek word  "a wolf."
:  Calydon was a city of tolia, which was situate in the centre of Greece.
:  This is intended as a reflection upon the proverbial faithlessness of the Carthaginians. "Punica fides," "Punic faith,' was a common proverb with the Romans.

:  There seems to be an equivocal meaning here in the word "tenetis," which may mean either "to understand," or "to take hold with the hand." "Dirumpatis" also may mean either "break off" a rope or cord, or "interrupt." Though Lambinus thinks that some indecent allusion is intended, this much more probable that Scaliger is right in supposing that allusion is made to the boyish diversion of two parties pulling at the ends of a rope till it either breaks, or one side lets go.
:  He will go to dress for a part in the Play; that of Agorastocles, as some have suggested.

stage: Pointing to the house of AGORASTOCLES.
Pointing to the house of LYCUS.
p.#text: I HAVE a mind to imitate the Achilles of Aristarchus from that Tragedy I'll take for myself the opening: "Be silent, and hold your tongues, and give attention." The head-manager it is who bids you listen, that with a good grace they may be seated on the benches, both those who have come hungry and those  well filled. You who have eaten, by far the most wisely have you done: you who have not eaten, do you be filled with the Play. But he who has something ready for him to eat, 'tis  great folly in him, for our sakes, to come here to sit fasting. Rise up, cryer! bespeak attention among the people: I'm now waiting  if you know your duty. Exercise your voice, by means of which you subsist and find your clothes; for unless you do cry out, in your silence starvation will be creeping upon you. Well, now sit down again, that you may earn double wages. Heaven grant success! do you obey my commands. Let no worn-out debauchee be sitting in the front of the stage, nor let the lictor or his rods be noisy in the least; and let no seat-keeper be walking about before  faces, nor be showing any to their seats, while the actor is on the stage. Those who have been sleeping too long at home in idleness, it's right for them now to stand contentedly, or else let them master their drowsiness. Don't let slaves be occupying the seats, that there may be room for those who are free; or else let them pay down the money for their places; if that they cannot do, let them be off home,  escape a double evil, lest they be variegated both here with scourges, and with thongs at home, if they've not got things in due order when their masters come home. Let nurses keep children, baby-bantlings, at home, and let no one bring them to see the Play; lest both they themselves may be athirst, and the children may die with hunger; and that they mayn't be squealing about here, in their hungry fits, just like kids. Let the matrons see the piece in silence, in silence laugh,  let them refrain from screaming here with their shrill voices; their themes for gossip let them carry off home, so as not to be an annoyance to their husbands both here and at home. And, as regards the managers of the performance, let not the palm  be given to any player wrongfully, nor by reason of favour let any be driven out of doors, in order that the inferior may be preferred to the good ones. And this, too, besides, which I had almost forgotten: while the performance is going on, do you, lacqueys, make an onset on the cookshops; now, while there's an opportunity, now, while the tarts are smoking hot, hasten there. These injunctions, which have been given as the manager's command, Heaven prosper them! troth now, let every one remember for himself. Now, in its turn, I wish to go back to the plot, that you may be equally knowing with myself. Its site, its limits, its boundaries I'll now lay down; for that purpose have I been appointed surveyor. But, unless it's troublesome, I wish to give you the name of this Comedy: but if it is an annoyance, I'll tell you still, since I have leave from those who have the management. This Comedy is called the "Carthaginian;" in the Latin, Plautus has called it "the Pulse-eating Kinsman." You have the name, then; now hear the rest of the story; for here will this plot be judged of  Its own stage is the  place for every plot; you are the critics; I pray you lend attention. There were two cousins-german, Carthaginians, of a very high and very wealthy family. One of them is  alive, the other's dead. The more confidently do I inform you  because the undertaker told me so, who anointed him  But the only son there was of that old man who died, being separated from his father, was stolen at Carthage when seven years old, six years, in fact, before his father died. When he saw that his only son was lost to him, he himself, from grief, fell sick; he made this cousin-german of his his heir; he himself departed for Acheron without taking leave. The person who stole the child, carried him off to Calydon,  sold him here to a certain rich old man for his master, one desirous of children,  a hater of women. This old man, without knowing it, bought the son of his host, that same child, and adopted him as his own son, and made him his heir when he himself departed this life. This young man is dwelling here in this house.  Once more do I return to Carthage. If you want to give any commission, or  to be managed--unless a person gives the money, he will be mistaken; but he who does give it will be very much more  But this father's cousin of his at Carthage, the old man who is still alive, had two daughters. The one when in her fifth year, the other in her fourth, were lost, together with their nurse, from the walks in the suburbs. The person who kidnapped them, carried them off to Anactorium, and sold them all, both nurse and girls, for ready money, to a man (if a Procurer is a man) the most accursed of men, as many as the earth contains; but do you yourselves now form a conjecture what sort of man it is whose name is Lycus. He removed, not long ago, from Anactorium, where he formerly lived, to Calydon here, for the sake of his business. Be dwells in that house.  This young man is dying distractedly in love with one of them, his kinswoman, not knowing that fact; neither is he aware who she is, nor has he ever touched her (so much does the Procurer hamper him); neither has he hitherto ever had any improper connexion with her, nor  taken her  nor has that  been willing to send her  Because he sees that he is in love, he wishes to touch  man for a  haul. A certain Captain, who is desperately in love with her, is desirous to buy this younger one to be his mistress. But their father, the Carthaginian, since he lost them, has been continually seeking them in every quarter, by sea and land. When he has entered any city, at once he seeks out all the courtesans, wherever each of them is living; he gives  gold,  prolongs the night  after that he asks whence she comes, of what country, whether she was made captive or kidnapped, born of what family, who her parents were. So diligently and so skilfully does he seek for his daughters. He knows all languages, too; but, though he knows them, he pretends not to know them: what need is there of talking? He is a Carthaginian all over. He, in the evening of yesterday, came into harbour here on board ship. The father of these girls, the same is the father's cousin of this young man. Now d'ye take this? If you do take it, draw it out: take care not to break it asunder; pray, let it proceed.  Dear me! I had almost forgotten to say the rest. He who adopted this  as his own son, the same was the guest of that Carthaginian, this  father. He will come here to-day, and discover his daughters here, and this person, his cousin's son, as indeed I've learnt. He,  who'll come to-day, will find his daughters and this his cousin's son. But after this, farewell!--attend; I'm off; I now intend to become another man. As to what remains, some others remain who'll explain  I'll go  dress. With kindly feelings do you  recognize me. Farewell!  give me your aid, that Salvation may prove propitious to you.

div2.stage: Enter, from his house, AGORASTOCLES, followed by MILPHIO.

p.#text: Full oft have I entrusted many matters to you, Milphio,  of doubt  necessity,  standing in need of good counsel, which you wisely, discreetly, cleverly, and skilfully have by your aid brought to completion for me. For which services I do confess that  your liberty and many kind thanks are due unto you.

note.#text: :   This word almost exactly answers to the word "bagatelles," or "kickshaws," borrowed by us from the French. As to the origin of the word "gerr," in the sense of "trifles," or "nonsense,' Festus gives the following anecdote:--"Osier-twigs, in bundles, were called 'gerr.' When the Athenians were besieging the Syracusans, and were often calling aloud for these fascines, the besieged, in ridicule, used to cry out, 'gerr, on which account that word came in use, to signify, in contempt,> anything trifling."

p.#text: An old adage, if you timely introduce it, is a clever thing: but your compliments are to me what are wont to be called sheer nonsense, and, upon my faith, mere bagatelles. Just now, you are full of kind speeches towards me; yesterday, without hesitation, upon my back you wore out three bulls' hides
But if, being in love, I did anything by reason of my distraction, Milphio, it's  reasonable that you should pardon me for it.
I've seen nothing more  I, too, am now dying for love; allow me to thrash you just as you did me, for no fault  and then, after that, do you pardon me being  in love.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If you have a mind for it, or it gives you pleasure, I do permit it; tie me up, bind me, scourge me; I recommend you, I give you my permission.

note.#text: :  "Pendeam." He alludes to the practice of tying slaves up by the hands for the purpose of being flogged.

p.#text: If, hereafter, you should revoke your permission, when you are unloosed, I myself should be hung up

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And would I venture to do that, to yourself espercially? On the contrary, if I see you but struck, it gives me pain immediately.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: To me, indeed, i' faith.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: No, to me.

p.#text: I could prefer that  But what now do you wish?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why need I tell a lie to you? I am desperately in love.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: My shoulder-blades feel that.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: But I mean with this damsel, my neighbour Adelphasium, the elder Courtesan that belongs to this Procurer.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: For my own part, I've heard that from yourself already.

p.#text: I'm on the rack with love for her. But than this Procurer Lycus, her master, not dirt  is more dirty.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Do you wish now to present him with some mischief?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I should like it.

p.#text: Why look  present him with me.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Go and be hanged!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But tell me seriously, do you wish to present him with a plague?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I should like it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Well then, present him with this selfsame me; I'd cause him to be having both a mischief and a plague.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You are joking.

note.#text: :  "Tuam libertam." "Your freed-woman;" you being the one to give her her liberty.

p.#text: Should you like this very day, without risk to yourself, to make her free?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I should like it, Milphio.

note.#text: :  The Philippean piece had the head of Philip of Macedon on it, and was in value about two guineas of our money.

p.#text: I'll manage for you to make her so. You have indoors three hundred golden Philippean pieces.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Six hundred even.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Three hundred are enough.

p.#text: To do what

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Hold your peace. This day I'll make you a present of the Procurer, whole, with all his household.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You shall soon know. Collybiscus, your bailiff, is in the city just now. The Procurer doesn't know him. Do you fully understand?

p.#text: I' faith, I understand  but what you are driving at I know not.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You don't know?

p.#text: Not  faith.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But I'll soon let you know. The gold shall be given him, for him to take to the Procurer, and say that he's a stranger from another city; that he's amorously inclined, and wishes to gratify his inclinations; that he wants free range to be found him, where he may secretly indulge his appetite, so that there may be no overlooker. The Procurer, greedy for the gold, will at once take him into his house; he'll conceal the man and the gold.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: The design pleases me.

note.#text: :  In consequence of his being unable to pay the penalty or damages decreed against him.

p.#text: Do you  enquire of him whether your slave hasn't come to him. He'll think that I am being sought for; immediately he'll say no to you. Have you any doubt but that the Procurer will at once have to double the gold for you, and be  to have stolen the man? Neither has he the means of raising it. When he comes to trial, the Prtor will award his whole household to you. Thus with a pitfall shall we deceive the Procurer Lycus.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: The design pleases me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Aye, when I've polished it up, you'll then say so still more even; now it's but in the rough.

note.#text: :  The Aphrodisia were festivals periodically celebrated in honor of Venus or Aphrodite, in most of the towns of Greece. The worshippers were, however, mostly of the class of courtesans.

p.#text: I'm going to the Temple of Venus, unless, Milphio, you wish for anything. It's the Aphrodisia to-day.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I know.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I wish to amuse my eyes with the harlot finery.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Let's first proceed to this, the plan we have resolved upon. Let's go in-doors, that we may instruct Collybiscus, the bailiff, how to plant this cheatery.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Although Cupid has the sway in my heart, still I'll listen to you.

stage: Goes to the door and calls.

note.#text: :  "Balistario." According to Lipsius, "balistarium" was the same as the balista itself; while Turnebus thinks it was the place where the 'balista" was mounted.

p.#text: I'll cause you to be glad it's done.  There is a speck of love upon this man's breast, which cannot by any means be washed out without great harm; this Lycus, too, the Procurer, is such a wicked person, against whom the engine of mischief is now well aimed, which before long I shall discharge from my battery. But see, here's Adelphasium coming out, and Anterastylis. The first is the one who renders my master distracted. But I'll call him out.  Hallo! Agorastocles, come out of doors if you would see most joyous sports!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What's this bustle, Milphio?

stage.#text: pointing to the door of LYCUS'S

p.#text: . Why, here's your mistress, if you'd like to see her.
O may the Gods bestow many a blessing on you, for having presented to me a sight so charming as this!

div2.stage: Enter ADELPHASIUM, ANTERASTYLIS, and an ATTENDANT.

p.#text: The man who wants to find abundance of employment for himself--a woman and a ship, these two things, let him procure; for no two things do produce more trouble, if, perchance, you begin to equip them; neither are these two things ever equipped enough, nor is the largest amount of equipment sufficient for them. And as I mention these things, from experience at home do I now say thus; for we two, even from daybreak up to the present hour of the day, have never ceased either washing, or scrubbing, or rubbing, or dressing, smoothing, polishing, painting, trimming, with all our might, and at the same time the two maid-servants, that have been provided for each of us, have been giving us their assistance in washing  cleaning; and in carrying water two men have become quite weary. Fie upon it! how great a plague there is in one female. But if  two, I know full well that they are able to give to any one, the mightiest nation whatsoever, more trouble than enough, in being night and day, always, at all hours, dressing, washing, rubbing, polishing. In fine, there's no moderation in women, nor do we understand how ever to set a limit to washing and scrubbing. But she who is washed clean, unless she is thoroughly dressed, in my notion at least, is just as though she were dirty.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: I really wonder, sister, that you talk in this fashion; you who are so knowing, and discreet, and clever; for when with all care we have ourselves in trim, hardly and with difficulty do we find poor pitiful admirers.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Such is the fact; but still reflect upon this one thing; a limit is best to be observed in all things, sister; all things in excess give too much trouble to mortals of themselves.

note.#text: :  "Salsa muriatica." Literally. "the pickle of salt-fish," which is supposed by some to have been the thunny

p.#text: Sister, prithee, do reflect that we are accounted just in the same way as pickled salt-fish is thought of--without any relish and without sweetness; unless full oft and long it is soaked in water, it smells badly,  is salt, so that you cannot touch it. Just so are we. Women of this class are utterly tasteless, and devoid of grace, without dress and expense.
. She surely is a cook, Agorastocles, according to my notion; she knows how to soak pickled fish.
. Why  troublesome?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Sister, do, there's a dear, forbear. It's quite sufficient for others to say that to us, not to be ourselves as well proclaiming our foibles.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: I'll have done, then.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I thank you: but now answer me this; are all things here which ought to be provided for propitiating the Gods?

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: I've taken care of everything.

p.#text: . How charming and joyous a day, and full of delight, worthy of Venus, by my troth, whose Aphrodisia are  to-day!

. Any thanks  for calling you out of doors? Oughtn't I now to be presented with a cask of old wine? Say it shall be given. Don't you answer me? His tongue has fallen out, I imagine. What, plague on it, have you been struck with amazement standing here?
. Do let me love on; don't disturb me, and do hold your peace.
. I'll hold my peace.
. If you had held your peace, why then that "I'll hold my peace" would not have been in existence.
Let's go, my sister.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: How now--why, prithee, are you now hastening that way?

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Do you ask me? Because our master is waiting for us at the Temple of Venus.

note.#text: :  "Schno." This is, by some, thought to have been a rank oil extracted from rushes. Meursius, however, ridicules the idea of an oil being made from rushes, and reads cno, "dirt," in the present passage.

:  She seems to refer to the lowest class of courtesans, and their seats in the prostitutes' sheds (mentioned by Ballio in the Pseudolus, l. 214) where they were exposed by the "lenones' to the public gaze.
:  "Diobolaria." Literally, "hired for a couple of obols."

p.#text: Let him wait, i' faith. Do you stay; there's a crowd just now at the altar. Do you wish yourself to be pushed about among those common prostitutes, the doxies of bakers, the cast-offs of the spelt-bread sellers; wretched creatures, daubed over with grease, followers of poor slaves,  stink for you of their stable and stall, their seats and very sheds; whom, in fact, not a single freeman has ever touched or taken home  the twopenny strumpets of dirty trumpery slaves?

. Away with you to utter perdition! Do you dare, then, to despise the slaves, you hussey? As if she was a beauty, as if kings were in the habit of making her their choice. A monstrosity of a woman! Diminutive as she is, she does spit out such mighty words--seven nights with whom I wouldn't purchase at a cupful of vapour.

. Immortal and omnipotent Divinities, what is there among you more beauteous? What have you that I should deem you more immortal than I am myself. in beholding with my eyes these delights so great? But Venus is not Venus; for my own part, her will I worship as Venus; that she may love me and prove propitious. Milphio!--hallo! Milphio, where are you?
. See, here I am with you.

note.#text: :  He puns upon the word "assum," which Milphio uses. He intends it to signify "here am I." But as it may also mean the neuter of the participle "assus," "roasted," Agorastocles chooses to take the sentence in the latter sense, as meaning "here I am roasted;" and answers, "I'd rather you were boiled."

p.#text: . But I want you boiled.
. Why really, master, you are making merry.
. Why, it was from yourself I learnt all this.
. What, even to be in love with her whom you have never touched? Really, that is nonsense.
. I' faith, the Gods as well do I love and fear from whom, nevertheless, I keep off my hands.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Alas! upon my word, when I look at the dress of us both, I'm grieved at the way we are dressed out.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Why really, it's quite in a proper style; for our master's gain and our own we are dressed quite well enough. For no profits can result, if the outlay exceeds them, sister; therefore, that is better to be had which is enough, than that which is more than enough.

p.#text: . So may the Gods love me, may she love me (I had rather she than the Gods), Milphio; why, this woman has it in her power to force a flint-stone to be in love with her.
. Upon my faith, in that you certainly tell no lie, for you are more senseless than a flint-stone to be in love with her.<

note.#text: :  There is a puerile and rather Indelicate play in this line and the next two upon the resemblance of the word "limus," "mud," and "limo," "to rub." An attempt has been made to give something analogous in the Translatio"

p.#text: . But consider  will you; I've never soiled her with a kiss. MIL. . I'll run, then, somewhere to a fish-pond or a pool,  fetch some soil.
. What need is there of that?
. I'll tell you; to soil her lips and yours.
. To utter perdition with you!
. For my part, I'm there
. Do you persist?
. I'll hold my tongue.
. But I wish you  always.
. Why really, master, you challenge me at my own game, and  you make fun of me.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: At present, sister, I suppose you think yourself quite well enough drest; but when the instances of other courtesans are compared, then you will be having the heartache, if perchance you should see any one more nicely drest.

p.#text: Envy was never inbred in me, my sister, nor yet spitefulness: I had rather by far that I was adorned with a good disposition than with gold; gold is met with by luck, a good disposition  by nature. I very much prefer for myself to be called good than fortunate. It more befits a courtesan to show modesty than purple; and more does it become a courtesan to show modesty than golden  Evil habits soil a fine dress more than mud; good manners, by their deeds, easily set off a lowly garb.
. How now, you; would you like to play a merry and a frolicsome prank?
. I should like.
. Can you,  give attention to me?
. I can.
. Be off home, and go hang yourself.
. Why? AGO. . Because you'll never again hear so many words as sweet  What need have you to live? Only listen to me, and go hang yourself.

note.#text: :  "Uva passa" were grapes hung up in the sun to dry, and then scalded, for the purpose of being used as raisins, or for making sweet wine.

p.#text: Why yes, if, like grapes that are drying, you'll hang together with me.
. But I do love her.
. But I, to eat and drink.
. How now, you? How say you--?
What is it you ask

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Do you see? My eyes which were full of dirt, are they clear now?

p.#text: . Why, even still there's a little dirt in the middle of the eye.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Lend me your right hand, please.

p.#text: . And would you really touch or rub her eyes with unwashed hands?

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Too great indolence has taken possession of us to-day.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: For what reason, prithee?

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Why, because we didn't come long since, before daylight, to the Temple of Venus, to be the first to place fire upon her altar.

p.#text: O, there's no need for doing that; those who have faces suited for the night  make haste to go and sacrifice by night; before Venus is awake, they are already hurrying with all haste to sacrifice; for if they were to come when Venus is awake, so ugly are they, upon my faith, I do believe they would drive Venus herself away from the Temple.
. Milphio! MIL. . Poor Milphio, i' faith! What do you want with me now?
. Troth now, prithee, do mark how she speaks honied wine!

note.#text: :  "Laterculi" were sweet cakes on biscuits, shaped like a tile or brick. The things here named were probably articles of homely diet, compared with honied wine.

p.#text: , Nothing at all, except tile- cakes, sesamum, and poppies, wheat and parched nuts.
. Do I seem at all  in love?

lemma.#text: Mercury is by no means in love with

note.#text: :  As being the God of Merchandize and Profit.

p.#text: .  to your loss, a thing that Mercury is by no means in love with.
. Why, really, by my troth, it befits no lover to be in love with pelf.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Let's go, my sister.

p.#text: Do, please, just as you like. Follow  this way.
I'll follow.
. They are going. What if we accost them?
. You accost them.
. In the first place, health to you, the elder; and you, the younger, health to you in the second degree of estimation;  you, the third, health to you, without any place in my estimation.

sp.speaker: ATT.
sp.p: In that case, faith, I've wasted my oil and my labour.

p.#text: . Whither are you betaking yourself?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What I? To the Temple of Venus.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why thither?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: To propitiate Venus.

p.#text: How now? Is she angry,  Upon my faith, she is propitious. I will even answer for her.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What are you about? Prithee, why are you annoying me?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Thus cruel? Alas!

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Let me go away, I beg of you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why in such a hurry? There's a crowd there at present.

p.#text: I know it; there are other females there whom I wish to see, and  to be seen.
How can it give you pleasure to look at ugly people,  to afford one  beauteous to be looked at?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Because to-day, at the Temple of Venus, there's a fair for the courtesans; there the dealers meet; there I wish myself to be shown.

p.#text: To wares unsaleable, its right to entice the buyer of one's own accord; good wares easily meet with a purchaser, although they may be placed in concealment. How say you? When, at my house here  will you lay your head and side by me?

note.#text: :  Which, of course, means never.

p.#text: On the day on which Orcus sends away the dead from Acheron.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I've got in-doors I know not how many golden coins in a state of madness.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Bring them to me; I'll make their madness pretty soon come to an end.

p.#text: . A nice one, upon my word!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Away to utter and extreme perdition with you, and go and be hanged!

note.#text: :  "Nimbata." According to some Commentators, this word is a substantive here, and signifies a "slight fillet," of the same colour with the hair which the women used to wear upon the forehead; the idea of Turnebus, however, that it is an adjective, signifying "cloud-like," seems more likely to be correct.

p.#text: . The more I look at her, the more insignificant she is, and a mere bauble.

stage: Raises it from the ground, and attempts to embrace her.
p.#text: Keep your prating to yourself; I'm tired of it.  Come, do lift up this outer garment.

note.#text: :  This she says, probably, because she is especially careful to avoid pollution, by contact with the male sex, when on the eve of worshipping the Goddess in her Temple.

p.#text: I'm in a state of purity; prithee forbear to touch me, Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What am I to do, then?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: If you are wise, you may be saving yourself your anxiety.

p.#text: What? Me not be anxious on your account? What are you about, Milphio?

note.#text: :  "Odium meum." He forgets that Adelphasium is only the  cause of his master's anxiety.

p.#text: . See now, my aversion, .  What is it you want with me?
. Why is she angry with me?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why is she angry with you? Why should I trouble myself about that? For that is rather your own concern.

note.#text: : See the note to the Casina, l. 26.

p.#text: On my word, it's all over with you this very instant, if you don't make her as smooth for me as the sea is at the time when the halcyon is rearing her young ones there.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What am I to do?

p.#text: Entreat  soothe,  flatter
I'll do so with all diligence; but see, please, that you don't afterwards be giving this ambassador  a dressing with your fists.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I'll not do so.

note.#text: :  The semicolon seems to be more appropriately placed before than after "ex multis."

p.#text: . Let's now begone.  Do you detain me still? You act badly; you make me many fair promises; of those many, the whole come to nothing at all. Not once, but a hundred times, have you sworn to give me my freedom. While depending on you, I have neither anywhere procured any other resources for myself, nor is this  at all visible. And thus none the less am I still a slave. Move on, sister.  Get you gone from me!
Utterly undone! Come now, Milphio, what are you about?
. My joy, my delight, my life, my pleasure, apple of my eye, my little lip, my health, my  kiss, my honey, my heart, my biestings, my cream-cheese----
. Am I to allow these things to be said in my presence? I'm quite distracted, wretch that I am, if I don't order him at full speed to be hurried off to the executioner in a chariot and four!
. Prithee, for my sake, don't be angry with my master. I'll make----

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Let me alone.

note.#text: :  Plautus evidently makes a slip here, forgetting that Calydon was in tolia, and not in Attica.

p.#text: You are too cross. He'll pay the money for you, and make you a citizen of Attica, and a free woman.
, But why don't you let me go away? What is it you want? Just as he wishes me well, in like manner do you wish me well.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: If, indeed, he has deceived you before, from this time forward he shall be truthful to you.

p.#text: Get you gone hence, will you,  trepanner.

note.#text: :  It was a common practice to take hold of the ears of the person kissed. The Greeks called this practice  because it resembled the mode of taking up a kind of jug, which was so called, by its ears.

p.#text: I'll obey  But on what terms--do you understand? Do let me prevail upon you; do let me take you by  little ears; do let me give you a kiss. By my troth, I shall now set him a> weeping, if I don't make you kind; and (unless I do make you kind he   will do it) I'm dreadfully afraid lest he should beat me. I know the harsh manners of this crabbed man. Wherefore, my delight, pray do let me prevail upon you.

stage: Giving him a blow at each sentence.

note.#text: :  "Trioboli." Literally, "of three obols"
:  "Colostra." This is the first milk after a cow has calved. It is much esteemed for its richness.

p.#text: . I'm not a man worth threepence, if I don't tear out the eyes and teeth of that whip-scoundrel.  There's your delight for you! There's your honey! There's your heart! There are your biestings! There's your health! There's your  kiss!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Master, you are rendering yourself guilty of impiety! You are beating an ambassador.

p.#text: More than that even still.  I shall now add the apple of the eye, the little lip too, and the tongue.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: When will you be making an end?

p.#text: Was it in that fashion I requested you to plead

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: How then was I to plead?

p.#text: Do you ask me  Why thus you should have said, you scoundrel: "his" delight, I do entreat of you, "his" honey, "his" heart, "his" little lip, "his" tongue, "his"  kiss, "his" biestings, "his" sweet cream-cheese, you whip-scoundrel. All these things which you spoke of as yours, you should have mentioned as mine.

. By my troth, I do entreat you, his delight and my own aversion; his full-bosomed mistress, my enemy and evil-wisher; his eye, my eyesore; his honey, my gall--don't you be angry with him; or, if that cannot be, do take a rope and hang yourself, with your master and your household: for I see that henceforth, on your account, I shall have to live upon sighing; and as it is, I've already got my back about as hard with weals as an oyster-shell, by reason of your amours.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, do you wish me to hinder him from beating you, rather than that he should not prove untrue towards me?

p.#text: . Do answer him in somewhat kindly terms, there's a dear, that he mayn't be annoying to us; for he's detaining us from our purpose.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: That's true. This one fault more will I pardon you for, Agorastocles. I am not angry.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You are not?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I am not.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: That I may believe you, give me a kiss then.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I'll give you one by-and-by, when I return from the sacrifice.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Be off, then, in all haste.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Follow me, sister.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And do you hear too? Pay all compliments to Venus in my name.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I'll pay them.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Listen to this, too----

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What is it?

stage: ADELPHASIUM, ANTERASTYLIS, and ATTENDANT go into the Temple of Venus.
p.#text: Perform the ceremony in few words. And do you hear? Look back   She did look back. By my troth, I trust that Venus will do the same for you.
What now do you advise me  Milphio?

note.#text: :  Some Commentators have fancied that a play is intended upon the resemblance of the word "auctio" in this line and "anctor" in the preceding one.

p.#text: To give me a beating, and  have an auction; for  really, upon my faith, with utter impunity you might put up this house for sale.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why so?

note.#text: :  He says that his master may sell his own house, for he seems to have taken up his abode in his (Milphio's) mouth m reference to his having continually to speak of him or to him.

p.#text: For the greater part you make your dwelling in my mouth.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do have done with those expressions.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What now do you wish?

note.#text: :  His liberty being a thing non-existent.

p.#text: I just now gave three hundred Philippeans to the bailiff Collybiscus, before you called me out of doors. I now adjure you, Milphio, by this right hand, and by this left hand its sister, and by your eyes, and by my passion, and by my own Adelphasium, and by your liberty----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why, now you adjure me by nothing at all.

p.#text: My dear little Milphio, my  occasion, my safeguard, do what you promised me you would do, that I may prove the ruin of this Procurer.
Why, that's very easy  Be off, bring here with you your witnesses; meanwhile, in-doors I'll forthwith provide your bailiff with my disguise and stratagems. Make haste and be off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I fly.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the common trick of slaves taking to flight.

p.#text: That's more my part than yours.

note.#text: :  Plautus designedly makes Agorastocles talk in this disjointed and unintelligible manner, both for the purpose of showing his own distraction and teasing Milphio. He does not, however, seem likely to hurt his own interest by his promises. Given connectedly, his words stand thus (as given in a Note to Warner's Translation): "Should I not give you your liberty to-day, if you do what you have promised--if you impose upon the pander, and deliver Adelphasium to me--I do not deserve so many Philippeans of gold as there are dead men in the shades, waves in the sea, or star in the sky."

p.#text: Should I not, should I not, if you effect this adroitly----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only do begone.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Ought I not this very day----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only do be off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: To give you freedom

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only do begone.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: By my troth, I should not deserve-ah!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Bah! Only do be off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: As many as are the dead in Acheron----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Will you, then, move off?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nor yet as many as there are waves in the sea----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Are you going to move off?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nor as many as there are clouds----

p.#text: Do you persist in going on

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nor as there are stars in heaven----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Do you persist in dinning my ears?

p.#text: Neither this thing nor that; nor yet, indeed, seriously speaking--nor, by my faith, indeed. What need is there of words? And why not?--a thing that in one word--here we may say anything we please--and yet, i' faith, not seriously in reality. D'ye see how 'tis? So may the Gods bless me!--do you wish me to tell you in honest truth? A thing that here we may between ourselves--so  me Jupiter---- Do you see how? Look you--do you believe what I tell you?

note.#text: :  Juno, in her displeasure against the city of Thebes, sent the Sphinx, in order to wreak her vengeance against the inhabitants. This was a monster with the face and speech of a woman, the wings of a bird, and the rest of the body resembling that of a dog or a lion. The monster proposed enigmatical questions to all with whom it met, and those who could not explain them it devoured. On the Oracle being consulted, they were informed that they would not get rid of the monster unless they could find out the meaning of a certain enigma, which was, "What is that animal that has four feet in the morning, two at noon, and three at night?" dipus, at length, explained this as meaning a man, who crawls on all-fours during infancy, during manhood stands on two legs, and, when old, makes use of a stick as a third leg to support him. On hearing this, the monster, in despair, knocked out its brains against a rock.

p.stage: He goes into the house of AGORASTOCLES.
p.#text: If I cannot make you go away, I shall go away myself: for really, upon my faith, there's need of an dipus as a diviner for this speech  who was the interpreter to the Sphinx.

He has gone off in a passion; now must I beware, lest, through my own fault, I place an impediment in the way of my love. I'll go and fetch the witnesses, since love commands me, a free man, to be obedient to my own slave.

note.#text: :  These, probably, were Mercury, the God of Profit. and Venus, the Goddess of Lust.

p.#text: . May all the Gods render him unfortunate, should any Procurer, after this day, ever immolate any victim to Venus, or should any one sacrifice a single grain of frankincense. For wretched I, this day, have sacrificed to my most wrathful Deities six lambs, and still I could not manage to make Venus to be propitious unto me. Since I could not appease her, forthwith I departed thence in a passion; I forbade the entrails to be cut, and would not examine them. Inasmuch as the soothsayer pronounced them not propitious, I deemed the Goddess not deserving. By these means I fairly played a trick upon the greedy Venus. When, that which was enough, she would not have to be enough, I made a pause. 'Tis thus I act,  thus it befits me  I'll make the other Gods and Goddesses henceforth more contented, and less greedy, when they know how the Procurer put a trick upon Venus. The soothsayer, in manner right worthy of him, a fellow not worth threepence, said that in all the entrails misfortune and loss were portended to me, and that the Gods were angry with me. In what matter either divine or human is it right for me to put trust in him? Just after that, a mina of silver was given me. But where, pray, has this Captain stopped just now, who gave it me,  whom I've invited to breakfast? But look! here he comes.

note.#text: :  Much learning and discussion have been wasted on this word, which probably is only intended as coined by the Captain, as a high-sounding word without any meaning.

p.#text: So, as I began to tell you,  sorry pimp, about that Pentethronic battle, in which, with my own hands, in one day, I slew sixty thousand flying men.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Heyday! Flying men?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Certainly I do affirm it.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Prithee, are there anywhere men that fly?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: There were; but I slew them.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: How could you?

note.#text: :  The hairy surface of the leaves of coltsfoot would serve to keep the pellets of birdlime together at the moment of being nurled from the sling.

p.#text: I'll tell you. I gave birdlime and slings to my troops; beneath it they laid leaves of coltsfoot.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: That the birdlime mightn't adhere to the slings.

p.#text: Proceed.  I faith, you do lie most egregiously.  What after that?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: They placed pretty large pellets of birdlime in their slings: with which I ordered them to be taken aim at as they flew. Why many words? Each one did they hit with the birdlime-they fell to the ground as thick as pears. As each one dropped, I straightway pierced him through the brain with his own feathers, just like a turtle-dove.

p.#text: By my troth, if ever this did take place, then may Jupiter make me to be ever sacrificing,  never propitiating him.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: And don't you.believe me in this?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I do believe, in the same degree that it is proper that I should be believed. Come, let's go in-doors, until the entrails are brought home.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: I wish to relate to you a single battle more.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I don't care about it.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Do listen.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Upon my faith, no.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Why then I'll break your head this distant, if you don't listen, or else be off to utter perdition!

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'd sooner go to utter perdition!

p.#text: Are you determined

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Determined.

p.#text: In that case, do you, then, upon  lucky day, the Aphrodisia, make over to me the younger one of your courtesans.

The sacred ceremony has  been to me today of such a nature--I put off all serious matters from today until another day. I am resolved to make it really a holiday. Now let's go hence in-doors. Follow me this way.

p.stage: They go into the house of LYCUS.
p.#text: I follow. For this day, then, I'm out on hire to you.

div2.stage: Enter AGORASTOCLES, and several ASSISTANTS walking behind him.

note.#text: :  He probably alludes to the time that the fine hour takes before it gets down to the holes of the sieve through which it has to pass. Some Commentators, however, fancy that it is a general allusion to the handmill, and that he means to tell them that surely they must have lost all their activity by their punishment at the mill.

p.#text: So may the Deities love me, there's nothing more annoying than a tardy friend, especially to a man in love, who's in a hurry in everything that he does; just as I'm leading on these assistants, fellows of most crawling step; they are more slow than merchant-ships in a calm sea. And upon my faith, I really did on purpose wave my aged friends; I knew they were too slow through their years; I apprehended delay to my passion; in vain I selected for myself these  fellows on their preferment, timber-legged, most tardy  Well , if you are going to come to-day, get on, or get off hence to utter perdition! Is this the way it befits friends to give their assistance to a person in love? Why sure, this pace was bolted through a fine floursieve; unless you have been practising in fetters to creep along thus with this step.

note.#text: :  This passage shows that they had formerly been slaves. It is not improbable that numbers of liberated slaves Were always to be found in the Forum, ready for money to offer their services as witnesses of any transaction, without reference to its morality. They are here called "advocati;" which literally means, "persons summoned to one's assistance." Slaves were not allowed to give evidence against freemen.

p.#text: Hark you! although we seem to you of the commonalty and poor, if you don't speak us fair,  rich man of highest rank, we are in the habit of boldly playing the mischief with the rich man; we are under no engagement to you, about what it is that you love or hate. When we paid money for our freedom, we paid our own, not yours; it's right that we should be under no restraint. We value you at nought; don't you fancy that we've been made over as slaves to your passion. It's proper for free men to go through the city at a moderate pace; I deem it like a slave to be running along in a bustle. Especially when the state is at peace and the enemies are slain, it is not decent to make a tumult. But if you were for making greater haste, you ought to have brought us here as assistants the day before. Don't you fancy it--not any one of us will this day be running through the streets, nor yet shall the people pelt us with stones for madmen.

note.#text: :  He refers to the practice of worshippers inviting their friends to the Temples, to join them in eating the portions that were left after the sacrifice. See the Rudens, where this practice is more fully referred to "In dem" may, however, possibly mean "to my house."

p.#text: But if I had said that I was taking you to a Temple to breakfast, you would have surpassed a stag in speed, or a man on stilts in your steps. Now, because I have said that I am taking you as my assistants and witnesses, you are gouty, and in the slowness of your pace have been outdoing the snail.

Why, really, is there not good cause for running swiftly, where you are to drink  eat at another man's expense as much as you please, until you are full, what you need never return against your will to your host, at whose expense you have been eating? But still,in some way or other, although we are poor men, we have at home something to eat; don't you browbeat us in such a contemptuous way. Whatever that very little is, that  of ours is all at home; we neither dun any one ourselves, nor does any one dun us. Not one of us is going to burst the veins of his lungs for your sake.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You are too warm; really, I said this to you in joke.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Consider it said in joke as well what we have said to you in answer.

p.#text: Troth now, prithee, do give me this aid of yours  a fly-boat, not a merchant-ship. Do hobble along at least, for I do not ask you to hurry.

p.#text: If you wish to do anything quietly and leisurely, we lend our aid; if you are in a hurry, it would be better for you to hire runners  assistants.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You understand (the matter I've informed you of), that I have need of your assistance with regard to this Procurer, who has so long trifled with me in my amour; that a scheme is to be planned against him about the gold and. my servant.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: All that we know already, if these Spectators know. For the sake of these Spectators it is that this Play is now being acted. 'Twere better for you to inform them, that when you do anything, they may know what it is you are doing. Don't you trouble about us; we know the whole matter; since we all learnt it together in company with yourself, so that we can answer you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Such really is the fact; but come, that I may be sure then that you know it, repeat the matter at length, and tell me what I told you just now.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Are you trying in this way whether we know? Do you suppose we don't remember how you have given three hundred Philippeans to Collybiscus your bailiff, for him to bring here to the Procurer, your enemy, and to pretend that he is a foreigner from a distance, from another city? When he has brought them, you'll go there to seek your servant together with the money.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You remember it by heart; you have saved me.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: He'll be for denying it; he'll suppose your Milphio is being looked for. He'll have to pay double all the money stolen; the Procurer will be adjudged to you. In this matter you wish us to be your witnesses.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We know full well: to undo the perjured Procurer, it's that you wish.

sp.p: You've got the matter right. See, Milphio and the bailiff are opportunely coming out together. He's coming rigged out like a nobleman, and appropriately, for the plot.

div2.stage: Enter MILPHIO and COLLYBISCUS, from the house of AGORASTOCLES, dressed as a person of quality.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Nicely.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Take care you understand them, please.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only take you care that your speeches are learnt by heart for this plot.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You are a capital fellow.

p.#text: . Really you could not have brought as many men better suited for this purpose; for not one of them is tongue-tied ; they are genuine men of the law-courts; there they take up their abode; there you may see them more frequently than the Prtor. sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: May the Gods confound you!

The whole matter,  in its order.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: In that case, do you, then, give me your attention. Do you know this Procurer Lycus?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: But, upon my faith, I don't know him, of what appearance he is. I wish that you would point this fellow out to me.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We'll take all care: we've been instructed quite enough.

sp.p: Then it's right, Agorastocles, that we should see this gold, that we may know what to say by-and-by as our testimony.

p.#text: Come  look at it.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: But do you make believe as though I were a foreigner.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Dear me! Crafty fellows, upon my faith!

Let's be off.  But you-has enough been said?

sp.p: Do you be off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I'm off. Immortal Gods, I beg----

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Nay, but why don't you be off?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I'm off.

p.#text: You do wisely.  Hush! be quiet.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: What's the matter?

p.stage: pointing to the door of the house of LYCUS
p.#text: This door  was guilty of a great indecency just now.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: What indecency is that?

sp.p: It rumbled aloud. AsSIST. May the Deities confound you! Get you behind us.

p.#text: Be it so.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We'll walk first.

. I'll return here this moment, Captain. I wish to find us some fitting guests, to join us. Meanwhile, they'll bring the entrails; and at the same time, the women, I suppose, will soon be making their appearance at home after the sacrifice. But why are such a number of people coming this way? I wonder what they are bringing? He, too, in the scarf, that's following at a distance, who is he, I wonder? He is not an tolian.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We greet you, Lycus. Although against our will, we give you this salutation, and although in a very moderate degree do we entertain good wishes for procurers.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: May you all be fortunate--a thing that I know for certain you neither will be, nor will Fortune permit it so to be.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: That is a treasure hoarded in the tongues of fools, to deem it gainful to speak amiss to their superiors.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: He who knows not the road by which to arrive at the sea, him it befits to seek a river as his own companion. I know not the way of speaking abusively to you. Now you are the rivers to me; you I'm resolved to follow. If you speak blessings, along your banks I'll follow you; if you utter curses, along your track I'll go.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: To do good to the bad is a danger just as great as to do bad to the good.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: You shall learn. If you do any good to the bad, the benefit is lost: if you do any bad to the good, it lasts for a length of time.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Cleverly said! But what does that matter to me?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Because for the sake of your own well-doing we came hither, although in a very moderate degree do we entertain good wishes for procurers.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: If you bring anything that's good, I give you thanks.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Of our own, we neither bring nor give you anything that's good, nor do we promise you, nor, in fact, do we wish to give it.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I' faith, I do believe yon; such is your kindly feeling. But what now do you wish?

p.#text: This person in the scarf, whom you see, with him Mars is angered.
.  so indeed with your own heads!

p.#text: We are now bringing him here, Lycus, to you, for tearing asunder.
. This huntsman,  will be going home to-day with some spoil; the dogs are cleverly driving Lycus into the toils.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Who is this person?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We really don't know who he is, except that some time since, after daybreak, when we went down to the harbour, at the same moment we saw him landing from a merchant-ship. Disembarking, he came up to us at once--he saluted us; we answered him.

p.#text: . The artful fellows! how cleverly they do enter upon the plot!
What after that?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Then he joined in discourse with us: he said that he was a foreigner, unacquainted with this city: that he wanted a convenient place to be found here, for him to indulge his appetite. We brought the man to you; if the Gods are favourable to you, it's an opportunity for you to ply your trade.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Is he eager to that degree?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: He has got gold.

p.#text: . That booty is mine.
He wishes to drink  wench.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'll find him a nice place.

. Very clever that, about the soldier! about Sparta, most capital!
. May the Gods and Goddesses bestow many blessings on you, for having given me kindly information, and finding me a choice prey.
Aye,  as he himself has told us, that you may receive him the better, he has brought three hundred Philippean pieces as a provision.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'm a king if I can to-day entice this man to my house.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Nay but, he really is your own.

p.#text: By my troth, prithee, do persuade him to take up his abode at my house,  the best lodging.

It befit us neither to persuade nor to dissuade a person who is a foreigner; you'll transact your own business, if you are prudent. We have brought the ringdove for you, even to the trapping-ground; now it's better for yourself to catch him, if you wish him to be caught.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Are you going now?

p.#text: . What about the matters that I commissioned you upon, strangers?

sp.p: May the Deities grant you many blessings, since you wish me well.

sp.p: They say that you are in search of a lodging.

sp.p: I am in search.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Upon my faith, for sure, I can provide you a charming one, if, indeed, you can put up with yourself being in a charming room, on a couch charmingly laid, a charming damsel cuddling you.

p.#text: You are in the  road, Procurer.

I'll cause, when you've bathed, the bathkeeper to set up unguent-shop there. But  all these things that I have mentioned let out their services for pay.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Because they demand ready money.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Why, upon my faith, you are not more ready to receive than I to give.

sp.p: Why then follow me in-doors.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What's the matter? What is it you want, witnesses?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Look to the right hand; your servant is paying gold to the Procurer himself.

sp.speaker: LYCUS

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: I follow you.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Well, well, walk on; and then we'll talk together about the other matters that remain.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Why then follow me.

sp.p: What do you advise me now?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We knew it.

sp.p: Why not?

. Let all soothsayers go hang themselves now at once. Why should I believe them in future, as to what they say? For they, just now at the sacrifice, told me that evil and the greatest disaster was portended to me. I have since then amplified my fortune with profit.
. Save you, Procurer.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: May the Gods bless you, Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You now salute me more kindly than hitherto.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: A calm has come, as though to a ship at sea. Just as the wind is, to that quarter is the sail shifted.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: May those ladies be well in your house, to whom I wish it, but to yourself I do not wish it.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: They are well, as you desire; not for you, though.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Send your Adelphasium to my house, to-day, please, upon this celebrated and famous festival, the Aphrodisia.

sp.p: Why so?
