It's a planned contrivance for them to deprive me of it, and to divide it among themselves. They are wanting to get away the lamb from the wolf. They are wasting their pains.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What, do you deny that either the gold or my slave is at your house?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I do deny it; and, if it's of any use, I make myself hoarse with denying it.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: You are undone, Procurer; for that person whom we told you was a Spartan, is his bailiff; who brought you just now the three hundred Philippean pieces; and that same gold, too, is in his purse.

p.#text: . Woe unto you!

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: That, indeed, is close at hand for yourself.

p.#text: Come, you hang-dog, give up the purse this instant. You are clearly a thief; caught by me in the fact.  By my troth, I do beg of you, lend me your aid, so as to see me bring my slave out of his house.

I' faith, I'm now undone for certain, beyond a doubt! This has been done on purpose that a snare might be laid for me. But why do I hesitate to betake me hence to utter perdition, before I'm dragged off to the Prtor by the throat? Alas! what soothsayers I've been having for my diviners, who, if they promise anything that's fair, it comes to pass but slowly; that which they promise as unfortunate, comes directly. Now I'll be off: I'll consult my friends in what way--they deem it best in especial for me to hang myself.

div2.stage: Enter AGORASTOCLES, from the house of LYCUS, driving out COLLYBISCUS.

p.#text: Be off you, get out you, that the witnesses may see you coining out from here. Isn't this my servant?

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: I' faith, I really am, Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: How now, villanous Procurer?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: He, with whom you have the dispute, has made off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I hope he's gone hence to utter perdition.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: It's proper that we should wish the same.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: To-morrow I'll bring my action against the fellow.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Anything further with me----?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You may go; put on your own dress.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: It wasn't for nothing that I turned soldier. I made a little booty in-doors. While the household of the Procurer was asleep, I got myself well filled with the entrails. I'll be off from here in-doors.

p.#text: . 'Twas kindly done by you. Assistants, you have lent me your good services. To-morrow morning I beg you'll meet me at the court of justice.  Do you follow me in-doors.  To you, farewell!

stage: (AGORASTOCLES goes into his house, followed by COLLYBISCUS.)
p.#text: And you, farewell!  This fellow wants a thing that's notoriously unfair; he thinks that we are to serve him at our own expense. But such are all these rich people of ours: if you do anything of service, their thanks are lighter than a feather; if there's any offence, they show vengeance like lead. Let's now go to our houses, if you like, forthwith, since we've effected that for which we lent our services, to ruin this corrupter of our fellow-citizens.

I'm awaiting in what way my plot is to proceed. I'm bent upon ruining this Procurer, since he torments my afflicted master; but he in his turn beats me,  strikes me with his fist  heels. It's a misery to be in the service of one who is in love, especially one who is debarred from  which he woos. Heyday! I see Syncerastus, the Procurer's servant, betaking himself from the Temple. I'll listen to what he has to say.

div2.stage: Enter SYNCERASTUS, with some cooking utensils, from the Temple of Venus.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the marks denoting the age of wine, which were placed upon the "amphor" or "cadi," the earthenware casks. These were stopped tight with wood or cork, made impervious to the atmosphere with pitch (as here mentioned), or with clay, or a composition of gypsum. On the outside the title of the wine was either painted, or inscribed in earthenware letters, which are here alluded to. The date of the vintage was denoted by the names of the Consuls then in office. When the vessels were of glass, small tickets, called "pittacia," were suspended from them stating to a similar effect.
:  He calls the worthless characters who are skulking in his master's house "vinarii," " vintners," from their love for wine, of which the Procurer seems to be in possession of a choice stock.

p.#text: It's quite clear that Gods and men neglect the benefit of him who has a master like a person of such character as I have  There's not another person anywhere in the world more perjured or more wicked than is my master, nor one so filthy or so defiled with dirt. So may the Gods bless me, I'd rather pass my life either in the stone quarries or at the mill, with my sides hampered with heavy irons, than pass this servitude with a Procurer. What a race this is! What corruptors of men they are! Ye Gods, by our hopes in you, every kind of men you may see there, just as though you had come to Acheron --horse  foot, a freed-man, a thief, or a runaway,  you choose, one whipped, chained,  condemned  He who has got  to pay, whatever sort of person he is--all kinds are taken in; throughout all the house, in consequence, are darkened spots  hiding-places: drinking  eating are going on, just as though in a cookshop,  in no less degree. There may you see epistles written in letters inscribed on pottery,  sealed with pitch: the names are upon them in letters a cubit long; such a  levy on vintners have we got at our house.

. Upon my faith, it is quite wonderful, if his master doesn't make him his heir; for really, the way he soliloquizes, he's making a speech over him  dead and gone. I'd both like to accost the fellow, and yet I listen to him with extreme delight.

note.#text: :  "Expeculiatas." He alludes to those slaves who, having run away from their masters, are lurking in the Procurer's house, where they spend all their savings (peculium), which, by rights, should go to their masters towards the purchase of their freedom.

p.#text: . When I see these things going on, I'm vexed that slaves, purchased at the heaviest price, should at our house be robbed of the savings which ought to go to their masters. But at last nothing is left visible: "badly gotten, badly gone."
. This man goes on talking quite as though he himself were an honest fellow, when, upon my faith, he himself is able to make worthlessness more worthless.
. Now I'm taking home these vessels from the Temple of Venus, where with his sacrifice my master has not been able to propitiate Venus on her festive day.
. Charming Venus!
. But our Courtesans, with their first ictims, appeased Venus in an instant.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: O charming Venus, once again!

p.#text: . Now I'll go home.
. Hallo! Syncerastus!
. Who's calling Syncerastus?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Your friend.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You don't act like a friend, in causing me delay when I've got a burden.

p.#text: But in return for this matter I'll lend you my aid, when you please,  when you give me your commands. Consider the agreement signed.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: If so it is to be, I'll give you my services in this----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Why that, when I'm to have a beating, you yourself may substitute your hide.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Get along with you.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I don't understand what sort of person you are.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I'm good for nothing.

p.#text: Be so to yourself,

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I want you.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But my burden is pressing me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Then, do you set it down, and turn your face to me.

p.#text: I'll do  although I have no leisure.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Save you, Syncerastus.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: O Milphio, may all the Gods and Goddesses favour----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What person, pray?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Neither you, nor me, Milphio, nor my own master, in fact.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Whom are they to favour, then?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Any one else they please; for not one of us is de serving of it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You speak wittily.

p.#text: It befits me

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I'm doing that which, clearly, adulterers don't generally do.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What's that?

note.#text: :  There is an indecent allusion in this passage which is modified in the translation.

p.#text: Bringing all off in safety.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: May the Gods confound you and your master!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May they not confound me. I could make them ruin him, if I chose--ruin my master, did I not fear for myself, Milphio.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What is it? Tell me.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You are a bad one.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I am a bad one.

p.#text: It goes  badly with me.

tell me,  you ought to be in quite other plight. Why is it that it goes badly with you, who have at home in superabundance what to eat,  what to drink? You don't give a single three-obol piece away to a mistress, and have her for nothing.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May Jupiter so love me----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I' faith, in the degree that you deserve, to wit.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: How I do long for this family to come to ruin.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: If you long for it, lend your aid.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Without feathers it isn't easy to fly: my wings have got no feathers.

p.#text: Troth,  don't pluck out  then, in the next two months, your arm-pits will be fit for flying.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Away to utter perdition!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Away yourself, and your master!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But, really, if a person knew him well, the fellow might soon be ruined.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: * * * Just as though you could be silent on any matter.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I'll keep the matter more strictly secret for you than that which has been told to a dumb woman.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I could easily bring my mind to believe you there, if I did not know you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Trust me boldly at my own peril.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I shall trust you to my cost, and still I will trust you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Don't you know that your master is a mortal enemy of my master?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: By reason of the love affair?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You are losing all your pains.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because you are teaching one that has been taught.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why, then, do you doubt that my master will do a mischief to your master with pleasure, so far as he can do, with his deserving it? Then besides, if you lend some assistance, on that account he'll be able to do it the more easily.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But I'm afraid of this, Milphio----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What is it that you're afraid of?

note.#text: :  "Crucifragium;" a word coined for the occasion

p.#text: That while I'm preparing the plot against my master, I may be betrayed by yourself. If my master knows that I've been talking to any individual, he'll forthwith be making me from Syncerastus into Brokenlegs.
On my word, never shall any mortal be made the wiser by me; only to my master alone will I tell it; and to him, too,  that he shall not disclose that this matter originated in yourself.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I shall trust you at my peril, and yet I will trust you. But do you keep this a secret to yourself.

p.#text: To Faith  it is not more safely confided. Speak out boldly (there's room and opportunity); we are here alone.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: If your master chooses to act with caution, he'll prove the ruin of my master.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Easily.

p.#text: Then let me be acquainted with this "easily,' that he may know it

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because Adelphasium, whom your master dotes on is free by birth.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: In the same way that her other sister Anterastylis is.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But how am I to believe that?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because he bought them at Anactorium, when little children, of a Sicilian pirate.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: For how much?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: For eighteen min.

note.#text: :  He asks this question, as thirty min was about the average price for a single slave.

p.#text: . These two for eighteen
And their nurse for the third. He, too, who sold them told him that he was selling persons who had been kidnapped: he said that they were free-born,  from Carthage.

Ye Gods, by our hopes in you! you mention a most interesting matter; for my master Agorastocles was born in the same place; he was stolen thence when about six years old; after that, the person who stole him brought him here and sold him to my master; that person adopted him  to his wealth, when he departed this life.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You mention everything that can render it the more easy; let him assert their freedom, his own countrywomen, in an action on their freedom.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only do keep silence and hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: He certainly will bring the Procurer to a backgammon, if he gets them away.

note.#text: :  "Calcem." By some this word is thought to be used for "calculum," a "chessman," and that reference is made to the use of the word "incitas" in the previous line, which was the mate or backgammon in the game of "duodecim scripta" (somewhat similar to our game of backgammon) and in which " calculi," "pieces" or "chessmen," were used

p.#text: Nay but, I'll cause him to be ruined before he moves one foot; 'tis so contrived

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant it so, that I don't continue the slave of this Procurer.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: On the contrary, upon my faith, I'll cause you to be a free man with myself, if the Gods are willing.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant it so! Do you detain me for anything else, Milphio?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Fare you well, and may happiness attend you.

p.#text: I' faith, that lies in the power of yourself and your master. Farewell, and mind that  things have been told in secrecy.
This has not been mentioned  Farewell.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But really it's of no use, unless this is done while it is warm.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You are right in your advice, and so it shall be done.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: There's excellent material, if you provide an excellent workman.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Can't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I'll hold my tongue and be off.

stage: SYNCERASTUS goes into the house of LYCUS.
Goes into the house of AGORASTOCLES.
p.#text: A  opportunity you've made for me.  He's gone from here. The immortal Gods do will my master to be preserved, and this Procurer utterly ruined; a mischief so great is impending upon him. Is it not the fact, before one weapon has been launched, then another presses upon him? I'll go in-doors, that I may recount these matters to my master. For if I were to call him out hither before the house, and, what you've  just heard, if I were now here to repeat the same, it would be folly. I'd rather in-doors be an annoyance to my master singly, than be  here to all of you. Immortal Gods, what misfortunes, what great calamities do this day await this Procurer. But now there's no reason why I should delay. This business is resolved upon; no pausing is allowed; for both this must be cleverly managed, which has just now been entrusted to me, and that plan as well which was formed at home must be attended to. If there's any delay, he who sends me a heavy mischance will be acting rightly. Now I'll off in-doors; until my master comes from the Forum, I'll wait at home.

div2.stage: Enter HANNO, followed at a distance by his SERVANTS.

note.#text: :  These eighteen lines (or, at least, the first ten) are in Punic, the native language of Hanno. The following is the meaning of them, as given by Plautus in the next eleven lines: "I worship the Gods and Goddesses who preside over this city, that I may have come hither with good omen as to this business of mine, on which I have come; and,  Gods,  me your aid, that you may permit me to find my daughters and the son of my cousin;  who were stolen away from me, and his son from my cousin. But here lived formerly my guest Antidamas. They say that he has done that which he was doomed to do. They say that his son Agorastocles lives here. To him am I carrying with me this token of hospitality. He has been pointed as living in this neighbourhood. I'll make enquiry of these who are coming hither out of doors." The learned Bochart, in his Phaleg, considers that the first ten lines are Punic, and that the other eight are, possibly, Lybic, of which the sense had been previously given in Punic; and, in fact, he quite despaired of translating them His translation of the first ten very nearly agrees with that given by Plautus himself. Samuel Petit, in his Miscellanea, considers the whole to be Hebrew, and translates his version (which consists of sixteen lines) as follows: 1. Give ear and attend, O Gods and Goddesses, under whose protection are the men of this city. 2. Receive as acceptable my prayers and my integrity. TwO daughters did I beget, my strength. 3. Urged on by fate, I caused them on each feast-day of the Gods to go to the gardens. 4. With much rejoicing, and on the day of song, there was a void. 5. The girls, being stolen, forsook me. Whither shall I go, pacing all chambers? 6. Where is he who bore them away? that I may remove the helplessness of my sorrow which he produces for me like fruit, in being the father of, and rearing, children. 7. They have said that here, assuredly, Agorastocles lives. 8. I have a token of hospitality, the likeness of Saturn (I'm carrying it), 9. Between us. May there be some end for my journey, that rest at last may be afforded to my integrity. 10. So that alone and wretched and afflicted I may not wander to and fro but rather that I may meet with my children, and pay my vows and oblations 11. To the Gods and Goddesses whom I've invoked as my advisers and assistants, 12. To purify my house from the griefs with which I was affected when I praised them. But they heard not my words, and I am most afflicted and am despondent in mind. 13. O my hope, come hither, and whatever troubles await me, cause me to endure them. Take courage from the truth of oracles, and of the responses of the God  from divinations, and forewarnings, and prodigies. 14. Be thou speedily fulfilled; arouse thyself and pray. Would that they could hear: grief would depart from a devout parent, and I should recognize Aristocles, my brother's son. 15. Attentively hear this lamentation, O God, my power, make haste to the truth of thy promise of my exaltation, O God, and my evil odours shall cease. 16. Lo!  from henceforth will I to the best of my means show honor, sacrificing spelt to all the Gods, and singing praises!!!

p.#text: . Hyth alonim vualonuth sicorathi si ma com sith, Chi mach chumyth mumys tyal mictibariim ischi, Lipho canet luth bynuthi ad din bynuthii. div2.stage: Enter AGORASTOCLES, from his house, followed by MILPHIO.

p.#text: . Do you say, Milphio, that Syncerastus told you that both of these women were freeborn,  stolen away from Carthage?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I do say so; and if you were willing to act wisely, you'd at once assert their liberty by an action on their freedom. For it's a disgrace to you for you to allow your own country-people to be slaves before your eyes, who were free women at home.

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods, I do entreat your aid! What speech is this that my ears devour! Surely the words of these persons are  chalk; how have they cleansed away all the dark spots  from me!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If you've got witnesses of this matter, I'll do as you bid me.

p.#text: Why  you to me about witnesses? Why don't you stoutly insist upon it? Some way or other, Fortune will be your assistant.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: It's much more easy to begin a thing than to bring it about.

p.stage: catching sight of HANNO, attended by his SERVANTS

note.#text: :  The "tunica," or "garment," which Hanno is wearing, has long sleeves, or "manic," which causes Milphio to ask if he is a bird, from their resemblance to wings.
:  He alludes to the practice of thieves making off with the cloaks of persons while bathing at the public baths.
:  Probably a nickname for an African, in ommon use it Rome.

p.#text: . But what bird is this, pray, that's coming hither with the tunic on? Is he from the baths, I wonder, enveloped in his cloak? I' faith, the countenance is surely Carthaginian. The man's a Gugga. I' faith, he certainly has got some ancient and antiquated servants.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Don't you see the fellows following, loaded with luggage? And, as I fancy, they've got no fingers on their hands.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why so?

note.#text: :  The Carthaginians, no doubt, borrowed this custom from the Syrians and Phnicians, with whom, as also with the Jews, it was prevalent.

p.#text: Why, because they go with their rings in their ears. I'll approach them, and address them in the Punic language: if they answer, I'll continue to speak in the Punic tongue if not, then I'll adapt my language to their usage. How say you, do you still remember anything of the Punic language?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nothing at all, i' faith; for tell me, how could I know, who was but six years old when I was stolen away from Carthage?

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods! very many freeborn children have been lost from Carthage after this manner.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: How say you?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Should you like me to address this person in the Punic tongue?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you understand it?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: No Punic man this day is a better Punic than I.

p.#text: Go and address him, as to what he wants, why he's come, who he is, of what country,  whence he comes. Don't be sparing

note.#text: :  "Hail."Milphio's knowledge of the Punic dialect was probably but limited, though in the sequel it appears that he does know something of it. The translation of these Punic expressions is from Warner's Translation, where the Punic is given in a form somewhat different from that found in the modern editions of the text.

p.#text: Avo!   Of what country are you, or from what city?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Hanno Muthumballe bachadreanech.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He says that he is Hanno from Carthage, a Carthaginian, son of Muthumbal.

sp.speaker: HAN. Avo! MIL.
sp.p: He salutes us.

note.#text: :  "My masters." Milphio says he is talking about "gifts," from the resemblance of the word to the Latin " doni," the genitive case of "donum " "a gift."

p.#text: Donni.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He intends to present you with some " donation" out of this; what, I don't know. Don't you hear him promise?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Salute him again in Punic, in my name.

p.#text: . "Avo donni" he tells me  to you in his name.

note.#text: :  This passage has been rendered, "Oh! what a son of tears!" Milphio says he is talking about his "bucca," or "cheek," being in pain. An attempt has been made in the Translation to preserve in some slight degree the resemblance.

p.#text: Mehar bocca!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Be that for yourself rather than me!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He declares that his "box" for his teeth is painful. Perhaps he takes us to be doctors.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If it is so, tell him that we are not; I don't wish a stranger to be mistaken.

note.#text: :  "We are no doctors."

p.#text: . Hear you. Rufen nuco istam.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: This is my wish, that in fact everything should be explained to him just as it is. Ask him whether he has need of anything.

note.#text: :  The Carthaginian tunic flowed loose, and was not fastened with a girdle. Milphio perhaps alludes to his being without a purse, which was generally supported by the girdle, and without which he might think that a stranger had no business in such a wealthy city as Calydon.

p.#text: . You who have got no girdle, why have you come to this city, or what is it you seek?

note.#text: :  "Open."

p.#text: Muphursa.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is it he says?

note.#text: :  I beg an entrance for Saturn. Milphio plays upon the very slight resemblance of "muphursa" to "mures," "mice." Under the name of "African mice," he probably alludes to "panthers" or "leopards," which had perhaps been recently shown by the diles, for the first time.

p.#text: Moin lechianna.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why has he come?

sp.p: I' faith, he says what's worthy of belief; do believe him, my father.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I do believe him.
